meta_data.title: Affiliation Metrics for Time Series Anomaly Detection
meta_data.abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of anomaly detection in time series data by introducing a novel set of precision/recall metrics known as affiliation metrics. These metrics are designed to overcome the limitations of traditional evaluation metrics in time series anomaly detection, providing robustness, locality, and theoretical grounding.

relate work.related papers: Tatbul et al.~\cite{tatbul2018precision}, Hwang et al.~\cite{hwang2019time}
relate work.comparisons with related methods: Affiliation metrics compare favorably against range-based metrics like RP/RR and TaP/TaR due to their robustness to adversary algorithms and locality insightful evaluation.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: The paper introduces affiliation metrics aimed at enhancing the precision/recall evaluation of time series anomaly detection tasks by offering robust, parameter-free, and locally interpretable metrics.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To address the limitations in traditional anomaly detection metrics by providing a set of metrics that are resilient to adversarial strategies and enable local interpretability.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Existing metrics are vulnerable to adversarial algorithms and lack interpretability on the local level.
high_level_summary.method summary: Affiliation metrics use distance calculations and probability formulations to evaluate the accuracy of anomaly detections with respect to time-bound categories.
high_level_summary.conclusion: Affiliation metrics offer a robust tool for unbiased evaluation of anomaly detection methods, surpassing existing methods in both precision and interpretability.

Method.description: The proposed method introduces affiliation metrics that leverage average distance and probability comparison against random sampling to provide a more comprehensive evaluation of time series anomalies.
Method.problem formultaion: Addressing the misalignment of traditional evaluation metrics when applied to time series anomalies.
Method.model: The method does not propose a new model but a new evaluation metric system for existing models.
Method.theoretical analysis: The paper provides proofs and theoretical insights into the robustness of affiliation metrics and their statistical behavior.
Method.algorithm step: 1. Calculate directed average distance. 2. Define zones of affiliation. 3. Convert distances to probabilities against random sampling. 4. Calculate final precision/recall by averaging individual probabilities.

Experiments.evaluation metric: Affiliation metrics, RP/RR, TaP/TaR, Classical Precision/Recall
Experiments.setup: Comparative analysis using open datasets with varying anomaly types and detection algorithms.
Experiments.results: Affiliation metrics showed resilience against adversary predictions and provided local interpretability that conventional metrics lacked.
Experiments.performance: Outperformed existing range-based metrics in resisting adversary algorithms and highlighted precision and recall for previously ambiguous regions.
Experiments.analysis: Individual event evaluation highlighted strengths and weaknesses in anomaly detection algorithms previously not considered.

conclusion.summary: The paper successfully introduces a novel affiliation metric that overcomes limitations in traditional metrics, ensuring robust, parameter-free, and interpretable evaluation of time series anomalies.
conclusion.future work: Application to other domains beyond time series anomaly detection, exploring hybrid distance and probability metrics.
